author: cf0009
content: https://twitter.com/lightclients/status/1387495468549160971

author: cf0009
content: I just noticed this on twitter

author: halfinney.
content: Thanks!

author: cf0009
content: the network is at 100% capacity, 100% of the day, and there's like 151k pending tx's ...

author: cf0009
content: wouldn't this make fees go exponential?

author: cf0009
content: 10 mins of full blocks = 10x (say 10 gwei), 20 mins => 100x (100 gwei), 30 mins => 1000x (1000 gwei?)

author: cf0009
content: this reminds me of the 'direct incentives' used in fei protocol, and they had to stop them within 3 days cos nobody dared using it cos they'd get rekt

author: timbeiko
content: It will make it go "exponential" until we reach the market price

author: timbeiko
content: post-1559, blocks can be up to 200% full

author: timbeiko
content: and the `BASE FEE` only goes up if they are >100% full

author: timbeiko
content: so assume the market price for gas is 100 gwei, we hard fork and the `BASE FEE` is 1 gwei

author: timbeiko
content: For ~10 minutes, you will have 200% full blocks as the `BASE FEE` goes up 100x

author: timbeiko
content: but at 100 gwei, the demand for blockspace will be equivalent to 100% of the gas limit, so the base fee will stay stable

author: timbeiko
content: (and if demand increases, then the base fee goes up, same for decrease/down)

author: timbeiko
content: Worth noting that the reason we have so many pending txns now is that we don't have a market price in the protocol

author: timbeiko
content: so post-1559, we can better know what the demand is at a certain price

author: timbeiko
content: and transaction who are not willing to pay that price don't really need to be "pending"

author: timbeiko
content: (they still can, but it's clear in the protocol that they are very unlikely to be included in the next N blocks)

author: cf0009
content: Can users still bid at whatever tx fee they want?

author: timbeiko
content: Well, each block specifies the minimum price you need to pay to be included, that's what the `BASE FEE` is

author: timbeiko
content: users specify the max they are willing to pay (`FEE CAP`), and get refunded the difference between their max and the base fee + miner tip

author: timbeiko
content: so for example, if the base fee is 100, and you want to give a 5 gwei miner tip, and put a fee cap of 200, you will get back 200-100-5=95 gwei

author: timbeiko
content: so if your fee cap is < than the base fee, then your transaction cannot be included in the block

author: timbeiko
content: but the base fee could lower in the next block if there is low demand, so in that sense you can still "bid", but it's basically betting on demand lowering

author: cf0009
content: Maybe I don't have the full picture. My bad. Thanks <@!552133098075193354>

author: timbeiko
content: No worries! There are a bunch of explainers for the EIP here: https://hackmd.io/@timbeiko/1559-resources

author: timbeiko
content: It dfefinitely takes a while to build the full picture üòÖ
